awd_titl_txt: SemiSynBio: Collaborative Research: YeastOns: Neural Networks Implemented in Communicating Yeast Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Large, three-dimensional cell colonies grown inexpensively using simple raw materials could be made into cheap, energy-efficient computers. A fundamental challenge in using living cells for computing is that computation by cells is error prone, and cells divide, die and reorganize inside a cell culture, making it difficult to maintain a defined architecture. This research will explore the design of yeast cell-based computing systems inspired by how computing is performed by the animal brain cells. To develop new knowledge at the intersection of electronics, computing and biology will require a new generation of students familiar with each of these areas who can work in collaborative teams. Building on work with organizations including the Freshman Research Initiative at UT Austin and Women in Science and Engineering at JHU, the PIs will develop programs to allow groups of undergraduate researchers to engage in long term research programs in which students have the opportunity to perform independent investigations as part of collaborative, inter-university teams.

This project will combine ideas from computer architecture and systems neuroscience with new tools from synthetic biology to develop yeastons - Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells that can collectively emulate a feedforward neural network through engineered cell-cell communication processes and programmable transcriptional logic. Crucially, yeaston networks will be designed to tolerate the inherent noisiness of single-cell biomolecular information processing and require no specific higher order spatial organization or patterning. The project members will build new protein receptors for small molecule signals and genetic logic systems that will enable single yeastons to emulate nodes in a feedforward neural network. The input-output behavior of single yeastons and yeaston networks will be quantitatively characterized, making it possible to evaluate the potential for scalable computation in yeaston systems. High-level models from neuroscience will be used to develop design principles for assembling robust yeaston networks and to derive scaling laws for yeaston computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Living cells represent a potential opportunity for new breakthroughs in information processing: large 3-dimensional cell colonies grown from simple raw materials could be dense, inexpensive computing architectures. While cells compute slowly, many cells together might process enough information. Critically, the energy efficiency of biomolecular computation can be 10,000 times greater than traditional computing.  However, a fundamental challenge to designing these architectures is the inherent unreliability of biological signal processing and the dynamic organization of cells due to death or division.  In this project, we investigated a scalable method for computing with living cells that addresses these fundamental challenges.  We considered whether cells might send molecular signals to nearby cells, which would process these to decide on the next computing step. Theory predicts that such a process if the radius of transmission were controlled so that only neighboring cells received transmissions, would allow for distributed computing similar to that performed by some artificial neural networks. We were able to precisely measure these transmissions and responses. We found that a critical ingredient for ensuring local transmission is that cells must not only secrete messenger ?signals?, but that these signals must be degraded so that they reach only nearby cells, not those that are further away.  We demonstrated the need for degradation using yeast cells that secrete small peptides.  We further investigated this idea using synthetic signaling processes that we developed in which synthetic RNA signals are used for communication and used this system to model simple distributed computing functions, including logic elements and an oscillator. 

 

In addition, during this project, we trained a diverse cadre of graduates and undergraduates. Undergraduates were supported as part of a research experience for undergraduates (REU) program.  Additional outreach included a talk at a Baltimore Science Fiction Conference and multiple high schools. This award also made it possible to start the Passport to Future Technology Leadership Program at Johns Hopkins, which has provided career exploration, professional development, mentorship, and job shadowing opportunities for 16 URM Ph.D. students. These students have won entrepreneurship awards and are now transitioning into careers in the biotechnology industry.   


 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2022
Modified by: Rebecca Schulman
